# For notebook plotting
%matplotlib inline

# Standard dependencies
import os
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

# Visualization
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy.interpolate import interp1d
import seaborn as sns
source.cee2d561:
# Read in data
DIR = '../input/'
freeform_df = pd.read_csv(DIR + 'freeFormResponses.csv', low_memory=False, header=[0,1])
multi_df = pd.read_csv(DIR + 'multipleChoiceResponses.csv', low_memory=False, header=[0,1])
SurveySchema = pd.read_csv(DIR + 'SurveySchema.csv', low_memory=False, header=[0,1])
source.21f6a82e:
# Format Dataframes
freeform_df.columns = freeform_df.columns.map('_'.join)
multi_df.columns = multi_df.columns.map('_'.join)
SurveySchema.columns = SurveySchema.columns.map('_'.join)

# For getting all columns
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)

source.c98865ec:
# Rename columns from multiple choice data
multi_df = multi_df.rename({'Time from Start to Finish (seconds)_Duration (in seconds)' : 'duration', 
                 'Q1_What is your gender? - Selected Choice' : 'gender', 
                 'Q1_OTHER_TEXT_What is your gender? - Prefer to self-describe - Text' : 'gender_other', 
                 'Q2_What is your age (# years)?' : 'age', 
                 'Q3_In which country do you currently reside?' : 'country', 
                 'Q4_What is the highest level of formal education that you have attained or plan to attain within the next 2 years?' : 'education', 
                 'Q5_Which best describes your undergraduate major? - Selected Choice' : 'major', 
                 'Q6_Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired): - Selected Choice' : 'current_title', 
                 'Q6_OTHER_TEXT_Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired): - Other - Text' : 'current_title_other', 
                 'Q7_In what industry is your current employer/contract (or your most recent employer if retired)? - Selected Choice' : 'industry', 
                'Q8_How many years of experience do you have in your current role?' : 'experience', 
                'Q9_What is your current yearly compensation (approximate $USD)?' : 'compensation', 
                'Q10_Does your current employer incorporate machine learning methods into their business?' : 'employerML?', 
                'Q12_MULTIPLE_CHOICE_What is the primary tool that you use at work or school to analyze data? (include text response) - Selected Choice' : 'primary_tool', 
                'Q17_What specific programming language do you use most often? - Selected Choice' : 'language_often', 
                'Q18_What programming language would you recommend an aspiring data scientist to learn first? - Selected Choice' : 'language_recommend', 
                'Q20_Of the choices that you selected in the previous question, which ML library have you used the most? - Selected Choice' : 'library_most', 
                'Q23_Approximately what percent of your time at work or school is spent actively coding?' : 'time_coding'}, axis='columns')

# Rename columns from free form data
freeform_df = freeform_df.rename({'Q1_OTHER_TEXT_What is your gender? - Prefer to self-describe - Text' : 'gender', 
                                  'Q21_OTHER_TEXT_What data visualization libraries or tools have you used in the past 5 years? (Select all that apply) - Other - Text' : 'viz'}, axis = 'columns')

female_perc = len(multi_df[multi_df['gender'] == 'Female']) / 23860 * 100
nospecifics_perc = len(multi_df[multi_df['gender'] == 'Prefer not to say']) / 23860 * 100

print('Of the 23860 people that answered the gender question:\n\
{:.2f} % of the participants are male.\n\
{:.2f} % of the participants are female.\n\
{:.2f} % of the participants did not specify their gender'.format(male_perc,

                                                                  nospecifics_perc))

              ax=ax,

              figsize=(14,5), 
              title='Age ranges')

source.98768178:
# Getting all columns from Q13 and renaming them
Q13 = multi_df.filter(like=("Q13"))
mapping = dict()
for i in range(16):
    old_index = Q13.columns[i]
    string = 'Q13_part_' + str(i+1)
    mapping.update({old_index : string})
Q13 = Q13.rename(columns=mapping)
# Getting value counts
data=pd.melt(Q13).dropna()
data=data[data['value'].apply(lambda x: type(x)==str)]
data=data['value'].value_counts()
# Plot
display(data.plot(kind='barh', 
                  figsize=(14,5), title="IDE's (Integrated Development Environments)"))
###############
print('{:.2f} % of respondents use Jupyter/iPython\n\
{:.2f} % use RStudio and\n\
{:.2f} % use Notepad++'.format(data[0] / 19117 * 100, 
                               data[1] / 19117 * 100, 
                               data[2] / 19117 * 100))

source.c8a712f4:
# Getting all columns from Q14 and renaming them
Q14 = multi_df.filter(like=("Q14"))
mapping = dict()
for i in range(12):
    old_index = Q14.columns[i]
    string = 'Q14_part_' + str(i+1)
    mapping.update({old_index : string})
Q14 = Q14.rename(columns=mapping)
# Getting value counts
data=pd.melt(Q14).dropna()
data=data[data['value'].apply(lambda x: type(x)==str)]
data=data['value'].value_counts()
data.drop('None', inplace=True)

                  figsize=(14,5), 
                  rot=25, title='Hosted notebook environments'))

print('Q14: Which of the following hosted notebooks have you used at work or school in the last 5 years? (Select all that apply)\n')
print('{:.2f} % of respondents have used Kaggle Kernels\n\
{:.2f} % have used JupyterHub/Binder and\n\
{:.2f} % have used Google Colab'.format(data[0] / 18971 * 100, 
                               data[1] / 18971 * 100, 
                               data[2] / 18971 * 100))

source.c3a7ea1f:
Preparation includes: 

* Importing dependencies
* Reading in data into Pandas DataFrames
* Formatting DataFrames.
source.99914f9b:
### DataFrame for the survey schema


Not everyone filled in all questions in the survey. The survey schema gives us more information about the amount of respondents that actually responded to a question.
source.2acd44c2:
Besides the standard answers, respondents could also fill in IDE's themselves. A lot of them are repetitions of the available answers, but some respondents mentioned interesting IDE's.

A selection of IDE's mentioned:
* [Google CoLab](https://colab.research.google.com)
* [Hadoop](https://hadoop.apache.org/)
* [NetBeans](https://netbeans.org/features/index.html)
* [Eclipse](https://www.eclipse.org/ide)
* [Emacs](https://eide.frama.io)
* [Watson Studio](https://www.ibm.com/cloud/watson-studio)
* [SAS Enterprise Miner](https://www.sas.com/en_us/software/enterprise-miner.html)
* [Oracle SQL Developer](https://www.oracle.com/database/technologies/appdev/sql-developer.html)
* [QT Creator](https://www.qt.io/qt-features-libraries-apis-tools-and-ide)
* [Maple](https://www.maplesoft.com/products/toolboxes/ide)
source.53656bbf: Most people in our community are in their 20's or 30's. However, it is interesting to see that there are many data scientists in the 18-21 (or younger!) range.
source.f519ab36: This plot is intentionally long to showcase the diversity of countries where Kagglers are residing.
source.ece16c7b: A large part of the Kaggle community also recommends aspiring Data Scientists to learn Python first.
source.6201798e: # Exploring Kaggle's 2018 ML and DS Survey!
source.966945df:
For those who didn't get the 'Unicorn' gender joke. Unicorn is a term used to denote a data scientist who can do everything and is very much in-demand for jobs.

Articles about "Unicorn Data Scientists":
* [Unicorn data scientist: the rarest of breeds](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/315758541_Unicorn_data_scientist_the_rarest_of_breeds)
* [Becoming a Data Science Unicorn](https://medium.com/@NileshMGupta/becoming-a-data-science-unicorn-879723111d42)
* [What’s the secret sauce to transforming into a Unicorn in Data Science?](https://towardsdatascience.com/whats-the-secret-sauce-to-transforming-into-a-unicorn-in-data-science-94082b01c39d)
* [How to Become a Unicorn Data Scientist and Make More than $240,000](https://whatsthebigdata.com/2015/10/17/how-to-become-a-unicorn-data-scientist-and-make-more-than-240000/)
source.f8d8422a:
My intuition that the community features a wide variety of educational backgrounds is confirmed. 

Nevertheless, it should be no suprise that a lot of people on Kaggle have a computer science, engineering or mathematics background!
source.bea18702: Finally, let's do some EDA (Exploratory Data Analysis)!
source.42db12e3:
Again, it should be no suprise that a large part of the community works in the technology sector.

Also, a large amount of Kagglers are students or are working in Academia/Education.
source.1fb3bb0b: The job titles look consistent with the industries plot.
source.76b1c4c7: We can safely say that the Kaggle community is well educated on average!
source.f54ae8d8:
Respondents also specified some interesting frameworks that were not part of the standard answers.

Less well-known visualization frameworks to consider:

* [Tableau](https://www.tableau.com)
* [Highcharts](https://www.highcharts.com)
* [Power BI (Microsoft)](https://powerbi.microsoft.com/en-us)
* [Dash (by Plotly)](https://plot.ly/products/dash)
* [Gnuplot](http://www.gnuplot.info)
source.1023c302: People who took the survey could also specify their gender themselves. To get these answers we have to consult freeform_df. Unfortunately, most people took this answer field as an opportunity for trolling.
source.2fee296d: As many of you may have noticed, [Kaggle launched a large scale online survey](https://www.kaggle.com/general/69534). They have been so kind to release the results as a public dataset. In this kernel I try to get interesting insights from this survey and explain these insights to you to the best of my ability.
source.d4c52d42: Kaggle logged how long it took for people to fill in the Survey. Let's take a closer look at this data.
source.34effaa5:
Assuming the gender distribution is representative of the community on Kaggle, it is unfortunate that this community is still male-dominated to such a large degree.

Some interesting articles about gender distribution among Data Scientists:
* [Data Science Demographics](https://www.datasciencecentral.com/profiles/blogs/data-scientist-demographics)
* [Forbes - The Data Science Diversity Gap](https://www.forbes.com/sites/priceonomics/2017/09/28/the-data-science-diversity-gap/#6c9ed96d5f58)
* [Why we need women in Data Science](https://www.betterbuys.com/bi/women-in-data-science)
* [Fighting the gender gap in Data Science](https://www.infoworld.com/article/3245531/data-science/fighting-the-gender-gap-in-data-science.html)
* [Quora - Is the female-to-male ratio higher for data scientists than for software engineers? If so, why is that?](https://www.quora.com/Is-the-female-to-male-ratio-higher-for-data-scientists-than-for-software-engineers-If-so-why-is-that)
source.d2910740: The Kaggle forums seem to be used a loved platform for Kagglers. Medium and ArXiv are also popular media sources. Twitter is not far behind as a popular media tool.
source.a54de6fe:
The versatile [Scikit-Learn framework](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/index.html) is the most widely used ML framework amongst Kagglers. [Tensorflow](https://www.tensorflow.org) and [Keras](https://keras.io/) are not that far behind. 

However, we see something different when looking at which ML library is used the most Kagglers. Scikit-Learn clearly comes out on top here. 

Personally, I'm a big fan of the new and still relatively unpopular [fastai framework](https://docs.fast.ai). It has a lot of versatility and implements a lot of state-of-the-art techniques.
source.72ba3559:
The most popular cloud platforms used by the Kaggle community are:

1. [AWS (Amazon Web Services)](https://aws.amazon.com)
2. [GCP (Google Cloud Platform)](https://cloud.google.com)
3. [Microsoft Azure](https://azure.microsoft.com)

Note that 37.44 % of respondents have used no cloud provider (in the last 5 years). I am curious why this is. 

Also, what is the impact of free GPU notebook environments like Kaggle Kernels and Google CoLab on cloud usage? This may be an interesting research question for a next survey.
source.43cef8fd:
Demographical data is found in the first questions of the survey. Let's look at some basic demographical data.

The columns are inconveniently named for our analysis, so we will first rename some columns. We can still consult the original questions later by looking at the [Initial Exploration](#3) section.
source.599d058f:
### Survey Methodology

This survey received 23,859 usable respondents from 147 countries and territories. If a country or territory received less than 50 respondents, we grouped them into a group named “Other” for anonymity.

We excluded respondents who were flagged by our survey system as “Spam”.

Most of our respondents were found primarily through Kaggle channels, like our email list, discussion forums and social media channels.

The survey was live from October 22nd to October 29th. We allowed respondents to complete the survey at any time during that window. The median response time for those who participated in the survey was 15-20 minutes.

Not every question was shown to every respondent. You can learn more about the different segments we used in the [schema.csv file](https://www.kaggle.com/kaggle/kaggle-survey-2018#SurveySchema.csv).

To protect the respondents’ identity, the answers to multiple choice questions have been separated into a separate data file from the open-ended responses. We do not provide a key to match up the multiple choice and free form responses. Further, the free form responses have been randomized column-wise such that the responses that appear on the same row did not necessarily come from the same survey-taker.

source.0caed031:
### Notebook environments

About 7500 respondents responded "None" when it came to which notebook environments they have used. I omitted this to clean up the visualization.

Top 3 Notebook environments used for work and school:
1. [Kaggle Kernels](https://www.kaggle.com/kernels)
2. [JupyterHub](https://jupyterhub.readthedocs.io/en/stable/)
3. [Google CoLab](https://colab.research.google.com/)

Although Kaggle Kernels comes out as the most popular notebook environment, not even a third  of the respondents (31.85 %) has used Kaggle Kernels for work or school. I think this is quite low since the respondents are all Kaggle users. 

What do you think? Should Kaggle do more to stimulate the use of Kaggle kernels for professional and educational use? Should they make Kaggle kernels more user-friendly for these purposes?

If so, how?
source.41d72105:
There is a reasonable distribution in how many time Kagglers spend on coding. The extremes are people that don't code and people who code ALL the time. I wonder how they do it!

source.3a7ac61e:
Every Kaggler has a toolbox and skill set that they use in competitions, implement in Kaggle kernels and talk about in discussions. 

Questions that come to mind: 

What are the most popular tools used? What are some obscure tools and methods that Kagglers specify in the freeform answers? How popular is cloud computing today and how many people use hosted notebook environments?
source.9f0fa07c:
Note: Respondents could select multiple answers

Jupyter/iPython Notebook is by far the most popular IDE for Kagglers. RStudio is also widely used and can be a good alternative for creating beautiful data visualizations (Like [Martin Henze](https://www.kaggle.com/headsortails) did in [his kernel](https://www.kaggle.com/headsortails/what-we-do-in-the-kernels-a-kaggle-survey-story) on this survey).

Notepad++ seems to be the most popular "text editor IDE".
source.65570d05:
### Kaggle statement

This year, as last year, we set out to conduct an industry-wide survey that presents a truly comprehensive view of the state of data science and machine learning. The survey was live for one week in October, and after cleaning the data we finished with 23,859 responses, a 49% increase over last year!

There's a lot to explore here. The results include raw numbers about who is working with data, what’s happening with machine learning in different industries, and the best ways for new data scientists to break into the field. We've published the data in as raw a format as possible without compromising anonymization, which makes it an unusual example of a survey dataset.
source.241c9594: [Matplotlib](https://matplotlib.org) is by far the most popular visualization framework, expecially since the second most popular framework ([Seaborn](https://seaborn.pydata.org)) is built on top of Matplotlib.
source.0139bc0d:
The most popular primary tool used by Kagglers is a local or hosted development environment like Jupyter or RStudio. The other ones are far behind, but are probably also widely used. Just not as a primary tool. 

For example, probably every Kaggler has used Excel at some point.
source.fdf83748: A lot of Kagglers are hesitant to share their yearly compensation. A large amount of people in the 0-10000 USD range are students.

One of the beautiful things of Kaggle is that people from different backgrounds come together to compete, discuss and share. Everyone is welcome to get involved and contribute! 
Let's take a look at the diversity of educational backgrounds.

source.fcd2766d:
Python is still the go-to programming language for Kagglers!

Top 3 programming languages used on a regular basis:
1. [Python](https://www.python.org/)
2. [SQL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL)
3. [R](https://www.r-project.org/about.html)
source.a4a6817b:
Kaggle gave us three csv files to analyze:

1. freeFormResponses.csv (Results from free form questions)
2. multipleChoiceResponses.csv (Results from multiple choice questions)
3. SurveySchema.csv (Response data)
source.4f80cd9b: This section was copied from the [overview section of "2018 Kaggle ML & DS Survey Challenge"](https://www.kaggle.com/kaggle/kaggle-survey-2018/home).
source.c8f30c9c:
A lot of Kagglers are just starting their journey and don't have a lot of experience yet. This makes sense, because a large part of the Kaggle platform is about learning and developing. This naturally attracts more students and less experienced people.

However, we also see a substantial amount of Kagglers with more than 5 years of experience. This makes the platform a nice ecosystem of students and professionals. Students are probably more concerned with learning and professionals with sharing and competing. 

This does not mean of course that students can't share or compete nor that professionals cannot learn from students. Everyone can compete, share and learn in the fast-evolving field of Data Science!
